7.47.text:
Hey, it’s Marie Forleo and you are watching
MarieTV, the place to be to create a business

14.01.text:
Today we are talking with an incredible actress,
businesswoman, mother, and wife.

19.68.text:
Like so many of us, she is multipassionate
and she’s here to share a bit about her

23.63.text: journey to creating a life she truly loves.

26.28.text:
Bryce Dallas Howard continues to be one of
the most versatile and dynamic talents both

30.80.text: on screen and behind the camera.

33.47.text:
As an actress, you may have seen Bryce in
the Oscar nominated film, The Help, starring

38.55.text:
in Jurassic World, or you can catch her now
in Disney’s Pete’s Dragon.

43.82.text:
Bryce made her film debut in M. Night Shyamalan’s
The Village.

47.83.text:
She also received a Golden Globe nomination
for her performance as Rosalind in HBO’s

53.03.text:
adaptation of Shakespeare’s As You Like
It.

55.76.text:
As a filmmaker, Bryce has directed over a
dozen short films and has received numerous

60.61.text:
accolades for her work, including being shortlisted
for an Oscar in 2012 for her film When You

68.35.text:
She’s the founder of 9 Muse’s Entertainment
and lives with her husband Seth, their two

73.12.text:
children, a hilarious puppy, a dignified elderly
cat, and countless captive bugs.

79.04.text: Bryce, thank you so much for coming on MarieTV.

82.47.text: Oh my goodness, thank you so much.

86.26.text:
I feel like I’ve memorized every single
thing on this set and, you know, and everyone

91.31.text:
that you work with are basically celebrities
in my eyes, so this is… this is amazing.

97.25.text:
Well, I love that we’re connected through
B-School, which we’ll talk about in a little

101.49.text:
But first I just wanted to let you know, the
more that I get to learn about you, the more

105.87.text: I fall in love with you.

107.23.text:
And that’s why I was so excited to have
you on the show today because you have so

110.27.text:
many incredible stories that are so relevant
for all of us as creatives.

114.94.text:
So let’s take it back, let’s travel back
in time.

118.95.text:
Most people know you for your knockout performances
like in Jurassic World and The Help and so

123.25.text: many other things that you’ve done.

124.69.text:
But what most people probably don’t know
is that you grew up with a learning disability.

134.26.text:
It was… looking back on it obviously it
was, like, no fun sort of as it was happening.

138.98.text:
But looking back on it I realized that it
really… it was a wonderful gift in a lot

144.95.text:
of ways because in getting diagnosed with
learning disabilities, in the going through

152.38.text:
I actually loved school, I loved my teachers,
I loved my friends, but it was very, very,

157.23.text:
very challenging for me and it was always
a struggle to keep up.

161.51.text:
And the only way that I was able to keep up
was getting very clear about what my strengths

168.53.text:
And so in hindsight it was fantastic because
people aren’t strong at everything.

173.37.text:
Like, they shouldn’t be because we all need
our specialized things that only we can do,

178.97.text:
like what, you know, that special gift that
only you have.

183.09.text:
And I think just going through all of that
I realized, ok, I’m very good at one thing.

191.79.text: I’m pretty good at 4 or 5 things.

196.91.text:
And that’s how I’m gonna live my life,
and it’s been really wonderful.

200.30.text: What exactly were your learning disabilities?

204.99.text: So basically the way it all evolved was when…

208.88.text:
I was a really happy kid, was always a happy
kid and sweet and stuff.

212.60.text: And so teachers liked me and everything.

214.29.text:
And so it always pained them so much to have
to, like, bring my parents in and say, “We

218.10.text: don’t know if she can go on to first grade.”

221.24.text:
Stuff like that, because I was working hard
and they just, you know, they all wanted me

229.41.text:
And it’s… the first kind of red flag was
actually when I was in kindergarten going

234.21.text:
into first grade and just not being able to
understand the concept of reading, not really

241.61.text:
And it was still early but everyone could
see that I was going to have significant reading

251.41.text:
As I got older, it became clear that there
were some other things as well.

255.35.text: I mean, these are, like, technical terms.

257.52.text:
I have a processing deficiency, which is amazing
because I got to take my SATs untimed, so

265.40.text: that was… that worked out for me.

270.03.text:
I need to take my time with certain things,
and that’s just a reality.

275.65.text:
I mean, I understand that it’s considered
a disability, but I don’t feel that being

281.63.text:
thorough is a negative thing, and I’m just
thorough.

285.94.text:
And then there was also a visual processing
deficiency, which is that basically I never

294.38.text:
know where I am at any time and I can’t
really… like, I get lost very easily.

299.35.text:
But as it applies to school, just conceptually
if I look at a map of the United States of

306.65.text:
America, I know where California is, I know
where Florida is, and I don’t think I know

314.64.text:
I have a general sense of things, but it’s

319.24.text:
I don’t know if it’s the geometry of it
or what it is, but it’s just… it’s tricky

327.84.text:
So when I was… this all kind of came to

334.91.text:
had been mounting in terms of, my school went
through 9th grade, getting into a high school.

339.11.text:
And a lot of the kids at my school were really

343.98.text:
Exeter and, you know, just like these very

And my teachers were concerned and so I went

358.62.text:
I learned about the learning disabilities,
but there were also things that came out of

363.07.text:
it where I realized what my strengths were,

again, I was in 7th grade, my math was at,

375.98.text:
like, a 4th grader’s level, my spelling

386.54.text:
And then, of course, you know, some challenges
with time and understanding spatial things

392.18.text:
But what came out of the test was that I am
actually in the top 1% of the world for common

400.38.text:
It’s called something a little bit fancier,
but that’s basically what it is.

407.77.text:
And then we also learned that as I grew older
and things became more about the big picture

413.27.text:
rather than the little details, that my mind

So the therapists were always kind of consoling

422.15.text:
with her, by the time she’s an adult this

structures and identifying the prepositions

That would be very hard for me still, but

442.07.text:
Like, this is… like, don’t worry about

449.50.text:

455.20.text:
at the time, who is still one of my closest

459.42.text: Levitt, and she is a genius.

468.72.text: I basically did everything that she did.

470.34.text:
So, like, whatever she was interested in,

And I admired her so much and I admired her

481.25.text:
in cinema, and… like, she got me into The

I just would really do anything that she would

489.02.text:
And she found this summer camp at Vassar,

495.55.text: where you could take college level courses.

And because she was going I was like, “I

506.65.text:

And so I remember looking at the application
because they were kinda like, “If you wanna

520.30.text:
do this you need to do this by yourself, because

probably wise up and quit before you actually

531.88.text:

537.47.text:

543.24.text:

557.29.text:
And I got in and I ended up going several

And I actually did start to piece together

577.15.text:
And so I just kept kind of after going to

582.97.text:
it suddenly I was like, “Oh, I’m one of

I reconceptualized kind of everything and

Because when I went to school I wasn’t the

was amongst these really impressive peers
who were all taking college courses in their

611.73.text: Well, I thought that I would feel inadequate.

Yes, definitely I felt inadequate at school,
but when I saw that I could get admitted from

And in 9th grade I was put in an English as

647.64.text:
And then by senior year I won the English

652.65.text:
And so it was… there was definitely… there
was definitely a kind of a significant journey

659.27.text:
that happened in a very short period of time

664.11.text:
Well, it goes to show the power of recognizing
a strength.

669.08.text:
Something that you can do even if there are

672.95.text:
that’s why I was really interested to hear

676.45.text:
of us can be in an environment where perhaps

680.03.text:
start to have that self talk that we’re

belong, and yet all it takes is that one discovery

687.63.text:
And I’ll say, with common sense, it’s

690.14.text: My mom, who loves the show.

And, mom, I love you, she’s always like,

Everything you say is really common sense,

important lesson she taught you playing the

And I admired both of them so much and my

And I would… any opportunity that I could

And when I was 16 years old, it’s the age

790.31.text:
You can’t gamble yet, but you can actually

And my grandmother was so excited because

So she would just, yeah, she would just get

And I think it sort of symbolized, I think

sort of the industry that they had been in

826.74.text:
just a really kind of crazy, unwieldy, uncertain

And so basically what happened was I went

And then by 64 she did actually book a job,

960.67.text:
So when I started auditioning after kind of,

966.39.text:
odds and being very inspired by her stick-to-itness,

And I promised myself I wasn’t gonna get

981.31.text:
64 auditions because that would be deluded

995.05.text:
I’ll get up to a hundred and then start

later asked me, because it was way over a

And just for the beautiful work that you’re
doing in the world and the way that you share

2998.42.text: Thank you, thank you, thank you.

3001.54.text:
This is just awesome being here and it’s
very meaningful, so thank you.

3007.72.text: Now Bryce and I would love to hear from you.

3010.53.text:
From all of the juicy stuff that we talked
about, what’s the single biggest insight

3014.01.text: that you’re taking away from today’s conversation?

3016.21.text: Leave a comment below and let us know.

3018.16.text:
Now, of course, the best things happen over
at MarieForleo.com, so head on over there

3025.59.text:
And when you’re at MarieForleo.com, make
sure you sign up for our insider’s list.

3031.32.text:
Instantly, you’ll get a download that I
created called How to Get Anything You Want.

3036.30.text:
Plus I’ll send you some exclusive content
and some special giveaways and insider updates

3041.29.text: that I don’t share anywhere else.

3043.48.text:
Stay on your game and keep going for your
dreams because the world needs that special

3050.84.text:
Thank you so much for watching and we’ll
catch you next time on MarieTV.

3055.57.text: Ready to find your voice and sell with heart?

3059.50.text:
Get started now with our free writing class
at TheCopyCure.com.
